awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity: The Dominican University STEM Success Model to Support Students through Critical Transitions
awd_abstract_narration:
The Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program (HSI Program) aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI Program will also generate new knowledge on how to achieve these aims.  This project will advance the aims of the HSI Program by implementing teaching and student support practices that can increase the success of undergraduates in early STEM courses. Research has shown that such early success can be crucial to student retention and long-term success in STEM fields, an issue of national interest. To promote success in introductory STEM college courses and support the transition from lower-division to upper-division coursework, the project will: (1) implement a STEM Summer Bridge program to prepare entering students for success in college-level STEM courses; and (2) transform first and second-year courses in biology, chemistry, and mathematics to promote engaged student learning and to enable diverse students to succeed in STEM fields. 

This project aims to enhance the quality of undergraduate STEM education and to increase retention and graduation rates of undergraduate students pursuing STEM degrees. Each intervention will include three components: (1) peer-led team-learning approaches and course-embedded tutors to improve academic performance; (2) inclusive pedagogy to improve student course engagement and student-faculty relationships; and (3) supplementary support through a Student Success Case Manager who will connect students to university and community resources related to financial, social, or emotional challenges, and who will facilitate their academic success. Project activities are designed to provide first-generation and nontraditional college students with the academic, psychosocial, and community supports needed to succeed in STEM. To generate knowledge, the project will investigate the extent to which the summer bridge program, peer-led team-learning, inclusive pedagogy, and case management improve academic performance and persistence in the first year, and evaluate the impact on student relationships, sense of community, and the effectiveness of academic supports for at-risk students. The student body at Dominican University is 74% commuter, 51% Hispanic, 50% first generation to attend college, and 49% low income.  This diversity is representative of nationwide demographic trends in higher education. Thus, evidence generated about the effectiveness of this project can have broad applicability for other colleges and universities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The HSI Program seeks to enhance the quality of undergraduate STEM education at Hispanic-serving institutions (HSIs) and to increase retention and graduation rates of undergraduate students pursuing degrees in STEM fields at HSIs. The 2019-2024 H.S.I. Program award (NSF Award #1832237) awarded to Dominican University, titled: Building Capacity: The Dominican University (DU) STEM Success Model to Support Students through Critical Transitions, focused on the early career stage of students pursuing degrees in STEM fields. To that end, STEM Success project implemented the following activities: (1) a summer bridge program to increase the academic skills of incoming students, (2) the use of embedded tutors employing peer-lead team-learning approaches to improve academic performance in key gateway STEM courses, (3) adoption of pedagogical approaches to improve student course engagement and student-faculty relationships, and (4) case management support to connect students to Dominican University and community resources to help them address financial, social, or emotional challenges to facilitate their academic success. 

 

The project had significant reach; a total 27 unique STEM faculty, from disciplines across Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics, Neuroscience, and Psychology were a part of the project implementation in faculty roles– either by leading a summer bridge lab experience or embedding tutors in their gateway class during a semester-long faculty community of practice experience, and many participated in both across the six years.  A total of 126 unique students were a part of project implementation in graduate student or undergraduate roles– either by serving as an embedded tutor, a project assistant, or a summer bridge mentor, and many filled multiple roles depending on the semester/summer of the project. Project participants included students enrolled in the first-year bridge program and/or gateway classes; the headcount for these participants exceeded over 60 and over 2,500 students, respectively. 

 

The outcomes of these interventions were positive; they served to increase the passing rate (grades of A, B, or C) found in pilot gateway classes, and to increase the yield by which students transitioned from STEM-interested incoming students to STEM-declared majors at the end of their second year. Graduation rates, while only available for a portion of the cohorts that participated in the project, also showed improvement. In addition to these outcomes for project participants, this project also provided a foundation by which Dominican University can continue to support its current and future enrollees (which includes significant numbers of first-generation, low-income students). Project approaches have been adopted by disciplines and initiatives outside of the initial scope of the design and increased collaboration is present among STEM disciplines and between academic and student affairs units. Project results have been disseminated at local, regional, and national scales in the form of conference presentations as well as a peer-reviewed publication (with additional manuscripts in preparation). 

 

Mokry, J., & Quinn, S. B. (2025). Peer-Led Team Learning in College Algebra. PRIMUS, 35(2), 214–231. https://doi.org/10.1080/10511970.2025.2460158

 


Last Modified: 04/11/2025
Modified by: Christopher Anderson
